Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Studies of Waves and Circulation Features in the Antarctic Stratosphere Using Super-Pressure Balloon Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project conducts research on the circulation of the Antarctic stratospheric polar vortex based on data from super pressure balloons (SPBs). SPBs have a semi-rigid envelope which, under pressure from the gas inside, maintains constant volume and hence constant effective density regardless of heating and cooling, so that they move with the wind along a nearly horizontal surface of constant density. Data for this project comes from two field campaigns,VORCORE (27 SPBs in 2005) and CONCORDIASI (18 SPBs in 2010), both of which launched balloons from Antarctica which rose to levels between 70 and 50mb and circulated within the polar vortex for several months. Instruments carried by the SPBs included miniaturized dropsondes, GPS receivers for occultation soundings, ozone sensors, and cloud ice particle counters. Research conducted under this award studies inertia-gravity waves and large-scale transport across and within the polar vortex, with four specific objectives: 1) The accurate statistical descriptions of the inertial and gravity wave fields over the Antarctic in the spatial and spectral domains, 2) The formulation of constraints for gravity wave parameterizations based on calculation of gravity wave momentum flux, 3) The influence of gravity waves on the formation of polar stratospheric clouds (PSCs, which play an important role in ozone depletion), and 4) The fundamental dynamical process at work in air exchanges and transports in relation to the polar vortex, with an emphasis on the role of Rossby wave breaking. The work uses a combination of observational analysis and modeling, and uses novel methods motivated by dynamical systems theory to address air exchange and transport across and within the polar vortex.

The problems addressed in the proposal are of societal as well as scientific interest for two reasons. First, the processes examined here are all relevant to the formation of the ozone hole, as ozone depletion depends on transport and mixing of stratospheric air across and within the polar vortex, and gravity wave motions may play a role in the formation of PSCs. Second, gravity wave momentum fluxes are thought to play an important role in determining the strength of atmospheric circulation, and the effects of gravity waves are paremeterized in weather and climate models. Thus, observational analysis of gravity wave properties may be beneficial for weather and climate modeling and prediction. In addition, the work will support and train a graduate student, thereby providing for the next generation of scientists in this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The present project concentrated on the stratosphere over Antarctica. Our specific objectives were the increased understanding of the wave fields over the Antarctic and emphasis on how these waves interact with the circulation and the polar vortex, and on how the presence of the vortex conditions the transport processes.  The Antarctic polar night vortex is a key contributor to the setting the conditions required by the special chemistry that produces the Antarctic Ozone Hole.

The research used a unique data set of the region gathered in situ by drifting super-pressure balloons launched during the field campaigns of the VORCORE and CONCORDIASI international projects sponsored by France’s CNRS and US’s NSF. For the wave analyses we applied formulations of wave fluxes in log-density coordinates developed in the previous funding period of this project. For the investigation of transport processes we used novel tools of Lagrangian analysis, which we were first to apply to studies on the stratospheric circulation.

(1)      Based on ERA-Interim Reanalysis data we built a 2D kinematic model capable of reproducing, by adjusting its parameters, vortex filamentation and breakdown features that are strikingly similar to the observation. Analyses of model results revealed the key kinematic mechanisms at work for the observed filamentation of the vortex (see Fig.1).

(1)          A novel definition of the stratospheric vortex boundary on isentropic surfaces was proposed and justified based on properties of dynamical systems in bounded domains (compact sets) in periodic or quasi-periodic cases. The boundary marks the poleward extension of the region of strong filamentation and mixing known as the “surf zone”). To our knowledge, other heuristic definitions of the vortex edge have not been similarly justified.

(2)          We introduced the new concept of normally hyperbolic invariant manifolds to the geometrical template that governs 3D transport in the stratosphere. To our knowledge, this concept had not been applied in stratospheric contexts.

(3)          The large-scale mechanisms at work for the unique splitting of the stratospheric polar vortex in the southern spring of 2002 were discussed.  We identified the behavior of air parcels during the split (see Figs. 2 and 3). Lagrangian structures used in this project were identified in the observational data. It was also concluded that the results agree with the notion that vortex interactions together with links between troposphere and stratosphere were key to the uniqueness of the event .

(4)          Momentum fluxes over the Antarctic Peninsula comprise a main distribution maximizing at small flux values and a secondary high flux distribution exhibiting a high degree of intermittency (see Fig. 4). The high flux events account for a large part of the average flux, which suggests that drag parameterizations in GCCMs should account for the conditions that favor them.  

Dr. Anirban Guha, who joined the team in 2013 as a postdoctoral scholar, was trained in stratospheric dynamics and numerical modeling of the atmosphere. Professor Jezabel Curbelo, an Assistant Professor of Mathematics, has been trained in stratospheric dynamics and transports.The work performed under this project represents a bridge between atmospheric scientists and applied mathematicians. The special Lagrangian analyses applied in the project had been used in oceanographic contexts for dynamical transports including the fate of oil spills in the ocean. The project has demonstrated their applicability to the stratosphere and the potential for future research.
